title: ASIA MARKETS: Asian Markets Retreat On Mixed Trade-war News
text:
By Marketwatch and Associated Press

Nikkei slips, mainland China stocks retreat ahead of 5-day holiday

Asian markets pulled back in early trading Monday, amid conflicting signals on the trade-war front.

China said Sunday that its top trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, will travel to Washington on October for renewed trade negotiations with the U.S. An exact date for the talks was not announced, but a senior Chinese official said "The two sides should find a solution through equal dialogue in accordance with the principle of mutual respect, equality and mutual benefit," the Associated Press reported (link).

On Friday, reports emerged about possible White House plans to restrict U.S. investment in Chinese companies. U.S. Treasury officials on Saturday denied any plans to do so "at this time," but also did not rule them out, leaving analysts and investors to wonder (link) if it was a negotiating tactic or a signal of a much harder line by the Trump administration.

On Monday, data showed China's manufacturing activity improved in September, though still in a state of contraction. The manufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 49.8 from 49.5 in August, according to the Wall Street Journal (link). According to a WSJ poll, economists expected a median forecast of 49.6.

Japan's Nikkei fell 0.5%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index edged up 0.2%. The Shanghai Composite slipped 0.3% while the Shenzhen Composite declined 0.5% ahead of the National Day holiday, which will shut Chinese markets until Oct. 8. South Korea's Kospi rose 0.3% while benchmark indexes in Singapore and Indonesia declined. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 gained 0.3%.

Among individual stocks, SoftBank (9984.TO) fell in Tokyo trading, along with Toyota (7203.TO) and Screen Holdings (7735.TO) . In Hong Kong, PetroChina (601857.SH) and China Mobile (0941.HK) rose, and Budweiser APAC -- the Asian spinoff from beer-maker Anheuser-Busch InBev -- opened higher in its massive initial public offering (link). LG Electronics (066570.SE) and SK Hynix (000660.SE) gained in South Korea, while Rio Tinto (RIO.LN) gained in Australia.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 29, 2019 23:21 ET (03:21 GMT)
